messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Palette Sparsification for Graphs with Sparse Neighborhoods

Paper Abstract: Abstract A celebrated palette sparsification result of Assadi, Chen, and Khanna states that in every n𝑛n-vertex graph of maximum degree ΔΔ\Delta, sampling Θ​(log⁡n)Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n) colors per vertex from {1,…,Δ+1}1…Δ1\{1,\ldots,\Delta+1\} almost certainly allows for a proper coloring from the sampled colors. Alon and Assadi extended this work proving a similar result for O​(Δ/log⁡Δ)𝑂ΔΔO\left(\Delta/\log\Delta\right)-coloring triangle-free graphs. Apart from being interesting results from a combinatorial standpoint, their results have various applications to the design of graph coloring algorithms in different models of computation. In this work, we focus on locally sparse graphs, i.e., graphs with sparse neighborhoods. We say a graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) is k𝑘k-locally-sparse if for each vertex v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V, the subgraph G​[N​(v)]𝐺delimited-[]𝑁𝑣G[N(v)] contains at most k𝑘k edges. A celebrated result of Alon, Krivelevich, and Sudakov shows that such graphs are O​(Δ/log⁡(Δ/k))𝑂ΔΔ𝑘O(\Delta/\log(\Delta/\sqrt{k}))-colorable. For any α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and k≪Δ2​αmuch-less-than𝑘superscriptΔ2𝛼k\ll\Delta^{2\alpha}, let G𝐺G be a k𝑘k-locally-sparse graph. We show the following for q=Θ​(Δ/log⁡(Δα/k))𝑞ΘΔsuperscriptΔ𝛼𝑘q=\Theta\left(\Delta/\log\left(\Delta^{\alpha}/\sqrt{k}\right)\right): • Sampling O​(Δα+log⁡n)𝑂superscriptΔ𝛼𝑛O\left(\Delta^{\alpha}+\sqrt{\log n}\right) colors per vertex is sufficient to obtain a proper q𝑞q-coloring of G𝐺G from the sampled colors. • There exists a single-pass streaming algorithm which computes a proper q𝑞q-coloring of G𝐺G with high probability using O~​(n​Δ2​α)~𝑂𝑛superscriptΔ2𝛼\tilde{O}\left(n\,\Delta^{2\alpha}\right) space. • There exists a randomized non-adaptive sublinear-time algorithm which computes a proper q𝑞q-coloring of G𝐺G with high probability using at most O~​(n32+α2​(1−α))~𝑂superscript𝑛32𝛼21𝛼\tilde{O}\left(n^{\frac{3}{2}+\frac{\alpha}{2(1-\alpha)}}\right) queries. Setting k=1𝑘1k=1 recovers the aforementioned result of Alon and Assadi for triangle-free graphs. For larger k𝑘k, our algorithmic results are an improvement over earlier work of Alon and Assadi. We establish our palette sparsification result in the more general setting of correspondence coloring where the structural constraints are placed on the correspondence cover as opposed to on the underlying graph. Such a notion has gathered much interest in recent years. A key element in our proof is a proposition which determines sufficient conditions on the correspondence cover ℋℋ\mathcal{H} for G𝐺G to admit a proper ℋℋ\mathcal{H}-coloring. This result improves upon recent work of Anderson, Kuchukova, and the author and is of independent interest.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Palette sparsification beyond (Δ+1)Δ1(Δ+1) vertex coloring",
        "Asymmetric list sizes in bipartite graphs",
        "Coloring graphs with sparse neighborhoods",
        "Coloring graphs with forbidden almost bipartite subgraphs",
        "Colouring graphs with forbidden bipartite subgraphs",
        "Coloring locally sparse graphs",
        "Brooks’ theorem in graph streams: A single-pass semi-streaming algorithm for ΔΔΔ-coloring",
        "Sublinear algorithms for (ΔΔΔ+ 1) vertex coloring",
        "Graph coloring via degeneracy in streaming and other space-conscious models",
        "The Johansson-Molloy theorem for DP-coloring",
        "On a list coloring conjecture of Reed",
        "Bounding χχχ by a fraction of ΔΔΔ for graphs without large cliques",
        "Independent transversals in bipartite correspondence-covers",
        "Vertex coloring complete multipartite graphs from random lists of size 2",
        "Coloring graphs from random lists of size 2",
        "Coloring graphs from random lists of fixed size",
        "Coloring graphs of various maximum degree from random lists",
        "Coloring complete and complete bipartite graphs from random lists",
        "Coloring triangle-free graphs with local list sizes",
        "Graph structure via local occupancy",
        "List colorings of kkk-partite kkk-graphs",
        "Bounds for the independence and chromatic numbers of locally sparse graphs",
        "Correspondence coloring and its application to list-coloring planar graphs without cycles of lengths 4 to 8",
        "Choosability in graphs",
        "A distributed palette sparsification theorem",
        "An average degree condition for independent transversals",
        "Introduction to property testing",
        "Near-optimal distributed degree+1 coloring",
        "A note on vertex list colouring",
        "Optimal thresholds for Latin squares, Steiner triple systems, and edge colorings",
        "Coloring Triangle-Free Graphs and Network Games",
        "Asymptotic choice number for triangle free graphs",
        "The choice number of sparse graphs",
        "Asymptotically good list-colorings",
        "Asymptotics for palette sparsification",
        "Asymptotics for Palette Sparsification from Variable Lists",
        "Thresholds for latin squares and Steiner triple systems: Bounds within a logarithmic factor",
        "Colourings, transversals and local sparsity",
        "The optimal edge-colouring threshold",
        "Fractional coloring with local demands and applications to degree-sequence bounds on the independence number",
        "On Brooks’ Theorem for sparse graphs",
        "Colouring complete powers of cycles from random lists",
        "Coloring complete bipartite graphs from random lists",
        "Independent transversals in locally sparse graphs",
        "On the threshold problem for latin boxes",
        "The list chromatic number of graphs with small clique number",
        "Graph Colourings and the Probabilistic Method",
        "A constructive proof of the general Lovász Local Lemma",
        "Randomized distributed edge coloring via an extension of the Chernoff–Hoeffding bounds",
        "Distributed coloring algorithms for triangle-free graphs",
        "The list colouring constants",
        "Asymptotically the list colouring constants are 111",
        "On a Packing and Covering Problem",
        "Coloring the vertices of a graph in prescribed colors"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Palette Sparsification for Graphs with Sparse Neighborhoods, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
